roleset.name: bring to land, from water or air, or metaphorical extension: (cause to) end up in a location
roleset.note: LAND-V NOTES: Frames file for 'land' based on sentences in financial subcorpus. No access to verbnet. Comparison to 'get'. (from land.01-v predicate notes)
LANDING-N NOTES: Based on sentences in nouns-00040. Comparison to land.01. VN class pocket-9.10-1. No FN class. Framed by Katie. (from landing.01-n)

roles.note: Pay attention to the difference between the pilot (arg 0) and the passengers (who will be arg 1). The passengers are not causing the plane to land, they're simply along for the ride. (from landing.01-n)

example.name: land-v: ergative, metaphorical
example.text: For all that, the piece landed unperformed in a dusty archive after Bologna refused to supply a chorus and orchestra.
example.arg: after Bologna refused to supply a chorus and orchestra

example.name: land-v: intransitive
example.text: At 18,000 feet, he says, [he and his co-pilot]-1 ``were looking for an interstate or a cornfield'' *trace*-1 to land.

example.name: land-v: transitive
example.text: After struggling for over an hour, John finally landed the 5-inch trout.
example.arg: After struggling for over an hour

example.name: landing-n: arg 1 (because they're not flying the plane, only riding in it)
landing-n: Here, 'the enemy' is actually doing the landing

roleset.name: get
roleset.note: LAND-V NOTES: I really don't know if the giver role can appear. (from land.02-v)

example.name: land-v: transitive
example.text: Mr. Wolf's success in that job helped him land the top job with UAL in December 1987.
